questions.question_text: When using | timechart by host, which field is represented in the x-axis?

comments.content:
Splunk docs (link above) clearly states "...with time used as the X-axis."
However, if you run "| timechart count", the field defaults to "_time". Thus, the visualization tab displays the "_time" on the X-axis. So this seems to be the case where the question/answer is referring to the documentation.
if you look at any figure in the link you reported above where a timechart is represented, you can see that the indicated field is _time

"A timechart is a statistical aggregation applied to a field to produce a chart, with time used as the X-axis"
Thus, ANS is Time
src: https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.0.4/SearchReference/Timechart

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
_time is the correct one
It says field, so it is _time. Time is not a field.

Selected Answer: D
Tested in my environment. The correct answer is "D - _time"

Selected Answer: D
_time is the answer.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. _time

Selected Answer: D
_time ans is D

Selected Answer: D
_time is the correct answer (verified in lab)

Timechart always has time on the X-axis
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Search/Createtimebasedcharts#:~:text=The%20timechart%20command%20generates%20a%2
0table%20of%20summary,field%20as%20a%20separate%20series%20in%20the%20chart.
D is the sure answer bro.

Selected Answer: D
Time will be the x-axis but we have remember which field stores time (_time). So the answer is D. That's a tricky question.

choices.A: | datamodel Web Web search | fields Web*
choices.B: | search datamodel Web Web | fields Web*
choices.C: | datamodel Web Web fields | search Web*

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct way to use the datamodel command to search fields in the Web data model within the Web dataset?

discussion.content: | datamodel [data model name] [dataset name] [search mode {search, flat, accelerate_search}]
A. | datamodel Web Web search | fields Web*

Answer is A.
See p279 of F2 PDF

choices.D: Events with the same JSESSIONID will be grouped together into a single event.
choices.A: An additional field named maxspan is created.
choices.C: An additional field named eventcount is created.
choices.B: An additional field named duration is created.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements describe the command below? (Choose all that apply.) sourcetype=access_combined | transaction JSESSIONID

discussion.content: B C D is the correct ans

BCD is the answer.
See p129 of F2 PDF
B C D is the correct ans

The transaction command adds two fields to the raw events, duration and eventcount.

| transaction [<field-list>]
One or more field names. The events are grouped into transactions, based on the unique values in the fields.

questions.question_text: Which of the following searches will return events containing a tag named Privileged?

comments.content: ^that's an example for a tag "privileged," not "Privileged"
Tags are CASE SENSITIVE and can use wildcard. So A: tag=Priv* is the correct anser.
"please don't comment the wrong answer, check the documentation before you post in the future :)" that's right Racgud, but take if for yourself since the ans is B!
lmao! Racgud got pwned hard. B is correct answer Tags are CaSe sentitive and can be used with wildards.

Please don't comment the wrong answer, check the documentation before you post in the future
That's an example for a tag "privileged"... the question talks about the tag Privileged. Tags are case sensitive so the answer is B=Priv*

D is the correct ans
"Verify that all privileged activity is returned. tag=privileged Returns privileged user activity data."
ref: https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/PCI/4.1.0/Install/PrivilegedUserActivity
please don't comment the wrong answer, check the documentation before you post in the future :)

discussion.content: the answer is B, tag are case sensitive. Privileged != privileged

Selected Answer: B
tags are case sensitive so it must be B

Selected Answer: B
Definitely B - done in a lab to make sure.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer because Tag is case-sensitive

comments.content:
Please do refer the this document
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/PCI/latest/Install/PrivilegedUserActivity

discussion.content: agreed with D. pls confirm friends.

Friends, the final answer is B or D?
Could you please confirm this answer?

comments.content: B is the right answer due to case sensitivity

discussion.content: tag names are case sensitive. In this case B is correct ans. Ref Fund2 : 196
D is the correct answer. Pg 197. The examples are listed

comments.content: Tags are case sensitive therefore Priv* is correct

page 193 shows that "Tags are case sensitive"
page 196-197 shows that tags can be searched through wildcard (*)

discussion.content: Tricky one but I agree with "kbisht" Correct Answer is B. Tag names are case sensitive and the question is: Which of the following searches will return events containing a tag named Privileged?, Capital letter P..... For example, "Privileged" and "privileged" are two different words because the "P" is uppercase in the first example and lowercase in the second example...See pages 194-196 in Splunk 7.X Fundamentals Part 2 PDF

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer.
If your macro have arguments you must specify them in parenthesis after the macro name (like <macroname>(<numberofarguments>))
When you specify the arguments you have to tell splunk what are the arguments name (without the $).
B is the correct answer, see p213 of f2

comments.content: And why it is not A? I mean there is nothing about macro name in that screen.
Nevermind I just realized that it is number of arguments.

questions.question_text:
Given the macro definition below, what should be entered into the Name and Arguments fields to correctly configure the macro?
//IMG//

choices.A: The macro name is sessiontracker and the arguments are action, JESSIONID.
choices.D: The macro name is sessiontracker(2) and the Arguments are $action$, $JESSIONID$.
choices.C: The macro name is sessiontracker and the arguments are $action$, $JESSIONID$.
choices.B: The macro name is sessiontracker(2) and the arguments are action, JESSIONID.
